ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Amazing class to learn analysis of poetry in a way that allows one to understand how poets think.

Attention to close reading - I appreciate how North made us get deep in exactly what each line/metaphor was saying on the page. At the same time, we also read some wonderful critical essays & framed each author in their biographical/historical context to get a broader picture.
Close reading of poetry
How to critically analyze poems and write essays about them.
I learned how to do critical literary analysis, to read closely, and learned a lot about modern poetry and poets.

I gained an improved ability to read poetry, both closely in terms of formal features and from a distance as part of a poet's larger body of work. I was familiarized with work from the 17th-21st centuries (both representative and atypical!).

I have a better understanding of the poetic canon and how to approach reading a poem carefully. The course made me think a lot about the role of poetry in academics and life; and I'm grateful to have been able to spend so much time with poetry.
poetry

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great way to learn poetry with a clear syllabus! Amazing feedback on papers, but would be nice to get them earlier.

strengths: great breadth of poets and poems, attention to close reading. I really, really appreciate Prof North's feedback on improving your writing - he spent an entire lecture getting us to think really critically how we use our language. I also don't think I've ever had a professor go so in-depth in their essay comments
weaknesses: could've spent more time on 70's/80's and contemporary poets
Strengths: Professor North, enjoyable list of readings/authors, engaging essays with extraordinarily helpful feedback

strengths: vigorous classroom discussion, detailed essay feedback
weaknesses: essay feedback and prompts given too late
Strengths: great seminar discussions, good essay feedback, interesting poems, great professor. Weaknesses: sometimes I wished that we would get more essay help but often i just went to OH for this

The reading list is excellent, and the writing assignments build upon skills developed in class discussions. I wish more of the readings could have been covered in class discussions and that perhaps more time was dedicated to a wider ranging view of the poets and poetry in general (perhaps aided through more literary criticism readings) rather than close reading.
Professor North was certainly a strength! As was the syllabus -- I loved the array of poets we read.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!!!!! It's such a great class to learn how to analyze poetry in an engaging matter.
yes, esp if you're an English major - just a good intro to poetry & western canon authors and critics
Yes; engaging readings and essays, clear feedback--made me a better reader/writer
This course focused mainly on four poets (Wordsworth, Dickinson, Thomas, Lorde).

Yes - even if you are hesitant about poetry (which I was) you learn so much and realize that single words can mean a lot in context. I have developed a new appreciation for poetry after taking this class and my writing has improved a lot, too.
Yes! Especially with Professor North. Great reading selection and teacher.
Only if taught by Prof. North.
Yes! If you're looking for an introduction to reading poetry. It was a great on-ramp to understanding how rhyme, meter, metaphor, etc. operate.
yes; more creative liberty
